meeting_sections.section_name: STUDY SESSION - CALL TO ORDER - Toyon Room (2:00 p.m.)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
AB 1417 requires all California community college boards of trustees to annually review and officially accept performance measurement data for their colleges that is included in the Student Success Scorecard Report. The report, which the State Chancellor’s Office provides to the state legislature, contains performance measures for each college.
 
The purpose of the report is to encourage colleges to improve their student success-related outcomes over time. Executive Director of Institutional Research David Ulate will present the 2015 Student Success Scorecard for Foothill College and De Anza College.
	 
The governing board will be asked to consider approval of the performance measurement data during the regular meeting.
	 
Submitted by:
David Ulate, Executive Director, Institutional Research and Planning
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_text: SS1. Student Success Scorecard Update (INFORMATION)

On March 20, 2015 and March 24, 2015, a Request for Proposal (RFP) #1732 was issued for Financial Advisory Services.  The following four firms submitted proposals by April 13, 2015, to provide financial advisory services:  
	 
KNN, Inc.; Public, Financial, Management Group, Inc.; Caldwell, Flores, Winters, Inc.; and Keygent, LLC

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
 
The District owns miscellaneous surplus property that is not satisfactory for further use by the District. California Education Code sections 81450 – 81452 provide that the governing board of a community college district may sell, donate, or dispose of personal property if it is unsatisfactory and no longer suitable for school use. The estimated aggregate resale value is less than $5,000.00. 
	 
District staff will assess and identify the most efficient manner to disposition the surplus that is in the best interest of the District and in accordance with California Education Code.
	 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to arrange for the sale, donation, recycle, or disposal of the surplus in accordance with the procedures set forth in Education Code sections 81450-81452.
items.item_text: Sell, Donate, Recycle, or Dispose of District Surplus

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The district’s Parking and Traffic Regulations permit the Board of Trustees to approve a waiver or reduction of parking fees. Foothill College Interim President Kimberlee Messina requests that the following parking lot rental fees be waived because these events are internal and/or are hosted by organizations that support the college mission:
	 
Wednesday, September 16, 2015 – Foothill College Parking Lot 1, 2 & 3 - $2,750.00 
Student Services requests free parking on Wednesday, September 16, 2015 from 7:00 a.m. - 10:00 p.m. for the New Student Orientation and the New Parent Orientation held in the Campus Center. The Office of Student Affairs & Activities estimates that 900 people will attend the New Student Orientation and an estimated 300 people will attend the New Parent Orientation. 
	 
Submitted by:
Kimberlee Messina, Interim President, Foothill College
Additional contact names:
Denise Swett
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College Interim President Kimberlee Messina recommends that the Board of Trustees waive the parking lot rental fees.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
De Anza College and Palo Alto University  request approval of a three-year academic and facility contract (2015-2018) to continue the program that provides De Anza College students a Bachelor Degree Completion opportunity, whereby qualified students of De Anza College who are enrolled in De Anza College's associate degree program will have the opportunity, after completing their transfer requirements, to enroll and participate in an academic program offered by Palo Alto University that will lead to receipt of the Bachelor degree from Palo Alto University.
	 
De Anza College's Academic and Facility Agreement includes a 20% non-profit discount.

Brian Murphy, De Anza College President, ext 8705

Susan Cheu, Vice President Finance and College Operations  ext 8976

Background and Analysis:
	 
The Board of Trustees annually reviews its list of priorities. Proposed priorities for 2015-2016 are:
Keep focus on student access, equity and success
Ensure that district facilities are modern and effective learning/working spaces
Maintain fiscal stability and solvency
Ensure that planning is integrated and progressing
Maintain community connections and board effectiveness
Strategies for accomplishing the 2015-2016 Board priorities are set forth in the attachment.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy C. Miner, Chancellor

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Joint Labor Management Benefits Council – comprised of representatives of each of the bargaining units and non-represented employee associations, the District and Retirees – has met to study and review the current benefit plans and projected cost increases for the 2016 Benefits Plan Year.
	 
The JLMBC has recommended the following changes in Employee/Retiree Contributions effective January 1, 2016 – December 31, 2016. The District shall continue to contract with CalPERS as its health benefits provider and shall implement the recommendations reached with and ratified by the participating unions of the JLMBC. A copy of the complete JLMBC Memorandum of Understanding is attached.
	 
The following includes the contributions for 2016, along with changes to the benefits plans.
	 
Active Employees and Retirees – 2016:
Rates for each plan and tier are expressed monthly, i.e., 1/12th of the employee annual contribution as specified below [based On Active-Retiree Contribution Illustration #19D, JLMBC, 6/25/15]:
	 
Three PPO Plans
            PERS Care                              January 1, 2016
            E                                              $480
            E + 1                                       $960
            E + family                               $1440
	 
            PERS Choice                           January 1, 2016
            E                                              $152
            E + 1                                       $304
            E + family                               $456
           
            PERS Select                            January 1, 2016
            E                                              $89
            E + 1                                       $178
            E + family                               $267
           
Seven HMO Plans: Bay Area
                    Anthem Select                         January 1, 2016
            E                                              $81
            E + 1                                       $162
            E + family                               $243
	 
    Anthem Traditional                January 1, 2016
            E                                              $214
            E + 1                                       $428
            E + family                               $642
	 
            Blue Shield Access+               January 1, 2016
            E                                              $375
            E + 1                                       $750
            E + family                               $1125
	 
            Blue Shield NetValue              January 1, 2016
            E                                              $393
            E + 1                                       $786
            E + family                               $1179
	 
            Healthnet SmartCare               January 1, 2016
            E                                              $167
            E + 1                                       $334
            E + family                               $501
	 
            Kaiser CA                               January 1, 2016
            E                                              $108
            E + 1                                       $216
            E + family                               $324
	 
            UnitedHealthcare                    January 1, 2016
            E                                              $480
            E + 1                                       $960
            E + family                               $1440
	 
	 
 Four HMO Plans: Other Southern California
            Healthnet Salud y Más           January 1, 2016
            E                                              $89
            E + 1                                       $178
            E + family                               $267
	 
            Healthnet SmartCare               January 1, 2016
            E                                              $89
            E + 1                                       $178
            E + family                               $267
	 
            Sharp                                       January 1, 2016
            E                                              $89
            E + 1                                       $178
            E + family                               $267
	 
            UnitedHealthcare                    January 1, 2016
            E                                              $89
            E + 1                                       $178
            E + family                               $267
	 
 Retiree Only: UHC Medicare Advantage Plan
            UnitedHealthcare 
            Medicare Advantage Plan       January 1, 2016
            E                                              $81
            E + 1                                       $162
            E + family                               $243
	 
In addition, employees shall have the option of enrolling in vision and dental coverage offered by the District.  The respective monthly contribution rates all include the cost of vision and dental coverage.  If a subscriber opts out of dental and vision coverage, the reduction in rates will be $6 for employee-only, $12 for employee-plus-one, and $18 for employee-plus-family.  The vision coverage remains identical to the plan currently in place. The dental coverage shall be modified by adding diagnostic/preventive care deductible waiver to the plan.
	 
Part-time Faculty 2016
The CalPERS Select plan shall be the “basic” plan and all other plans shall be a “buy-up.” The benefits shall have three load thresholds, each with a respective District contribution to the premium cost.  For employees with loads of .4 up to .499, the District shall be responsible for payment of forty percent (40%) of the Select monthly plan premium or the dollar equivalent under the other plan options.  For employees with loads of .5 up to .599, the District shall be responsible for payment of fifty percent (50%) of the Select monthly plan premium or the dollar equivalent under the other plan options.  For employees with loads of .6 up to .67, the District shall be responsible for payment of sixty percent (60%) of the Select monthly plan premium or the dollar equivalent under the other plan options. The employee shall be responsible for the remainder of the monthly plan premium for the coverage elected. 
	 
Effective January 1 – December 30, 2016, the following monthly rates shall apply:

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Change Order #5
Vendor:  Pullman Construction 
Agreement Date:  February 3, 2015
Campus:  De Anza College
Project Number:  216
Project Name:  Bid 1698
Amount:  $160,874.04
For:
	 
Change order for work to be performed on Time & Material for the unforeseen structural repair to the existing building and rooftop curb to allow for the new chiller anchorage. Funding for this work was not included in the original budget. The Contractor discovered the deficiency when attempting to perform contract work to install the new chiller isolator anchors.  
	 
The new scope of work includes selective demolition of portions of the existing concrete equipment pad; pouring new concrete infill beams that dowel into the building structure; and pouring new reinforced concrete equipment pad portions.  In addition, the Contractor will remove the already-installed contract sheet metal cap and re-work the roofing, as well as install a new sheet metal cap with new underlayment to again weatherproof the system.
	 
All work to be performed per new DSA-approved details and inspection via the Special Inspections & Testing Lab, as well as on-site inspection per the DSA Inspector of Record.
	 
The total Change Orders to date represent 48.7% against the original contract amount, half of which are attributable to the fact that the cost of temporary chillers was not included in the original budget. Funding for this project will be from 2015-2016 State Block Grant money.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Tom Armstrong, Director, Bond Program Management, De Anza College
Donna Jones-Dulin, Associate Vice President, Finance & Educational Resources, De Anza College
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approval
items.item_text: Pullman Construction - Change Order #5 - Science Center Chiller Replacement - $160,874.04 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Change Order #4 ot Early Site Work Phase
Vendor:  C.W. Driver
Agreement Date:  November 3, 2014
Campus:  FHDA Education Center
Project Number:  801
Project Name:  FHDA Education Center
Amount:  $30,363.00
For:
	 
Additional asphalt paving repairs along Innovation Way.  This work repairs existing paving weaknesses identified by City of Sunnyvale inspectors.  The street work is being built to City standards in accordance with the Memorandum of Agreement with between the District and the City.   Most of the worn pavement has developed during demolition and design activities, so its repair was not included in the bid documents.
	 
This change plus all previously approved change orders amounts to 13.7% of the base contract value.  Most of the change cost to date has been for work being done in cooperation with the Veterans Administration, for which the District will be repaid.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Management Program, Foothill College
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approval

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Prime Contract Change Order #9
Vendor:  DL Falk Construction 
Agreement Date:  August 4, 2014
Campus:  De Anza College
Project Number:  216
Project Name:  Library
Amount:  $8,206
For:
 
Prime Contract Change Order #09 - revises the original contract sum between the District and D.L. Falk Construction, and is required to repair discovered areas and to allow for the installation of new finishes.
	 
PCO 062 COR#59 RFI#224 at room 113 float out existing concrete columns to match existing of new sheetrock walls being installed.  Existing walls were found to be out of plumb. (FC)
	 
PCO 063  COR #60 RFI#153 Floor Leveling at 1st floor – unforeseen existing conditions were found to have several locations where concrete was used to level the floor where framed walls were installed. Contractor to grind floor, install floor leveler and prime to bring floor level to existing. (FC)
	 
The total Change Orders to date represent 15.67% against the original contract amount.  Funding is included in the construction budget.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Tom Armstrong, Director, Bond Program Management, De Anza College
Donna Jones-Dulin, Associate Vice President, Finance & Educational Resources, De Anza College
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approval

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This project will require the contractor to drill a 10” diameter borehole approximately 300’ deep water well for the purpose of locating underground water sources on the Foothill College campus to tie into existing irrigation.  The drill depth of the well is longer than the average depth and it is anticipated that the drilling will penetrate through rock.  The scope of work also requires minor electrical work to install a submersible pump and minor concrete work to prepare and pour a concrete pad for the well and electrical connections.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on April 10 and April 17, 2014. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builder’s exchanges and advertised in the San Jose Post Record as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on May 14, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office. Only one (1) contractor submitted a bid, Calstate Construction, Inc., at a price of $149,500 for the Base Bid Proposal Amount.
	 
Calstate Construction, Inc. has confirmed that its bid amount of $149,500 is true and accurate for the work as specified and it will subcontract the well drilling to one of the premier well drillers in the Bay Area.  Calstate previously completed the DOB Swing Space project at Foothill College and also the G Building Renovation project at De Anza College. It is currently under contract for the Kiosks at De Anza College.
	 
Measure C scheduled maintenance will fund the project. 
	 
Included as an attachment is background information including a summary of actions taken prior to bid award and information regarding groundwater conditions in the area.
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey - Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
  Steve Kitchen - Director of Facilities & Operations, Jennifer Mahato - Project Manager
Is backup provided?
  Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document 1729-100M – Well Drilling & Development at Foothill College in the amount of $149,500 to Calstate Construction, Inc.
